subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 20th September 2019: China leaving US early raises concerns into the weekend
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 20th September 2019: China leaving US early raises concerns into the weekend

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude up

* REAR VIEW: Chinese head home early, amid Trump saying ag. purchases alone won’t do; NY Fed provides repo operation timetable; Fed’s Bullard, Rosengren, and Clarida

* NEXT WEEK: MON: Eurozone & US PMIs. TUE: High-level UN General Assembly, German IFO. WED: RBNZ Rate Decision, US New Home Sales. THU: ECB Economic Bulletin, US GDP (F), Pending Home Sales, Banxico Rate Decision. FRI: US Durables, PCE, Core PCE, Personal Spending & Income. Click here to download RANsquawk Week in Focus.

 

* US-CHINA: The US removed 400 products from the tariff list, however the overall dollar amount was unknown, and the goods excluded included items such as: Single-cup coffee filters, plastic straws, Christmas tree lights, dog leashes and skateboards. The tariff exemptions follow requests from US companies, and as the exemptions are not on key items, it is hardly a significant step on improving relations between the two nations. However, US President Trump did state that a lot of progress is being made. Adding, he has an amazing relationship with Xi, but are currently having a ‘little spat’. On a deal, Trump stated Chinese agricultural purchases will not be enough, he wants a complete deal and that he does not need a deal before the 2020 election, reiterating China is 'eating' the tariffs. On an interim deal, US President Trump is reportedly not interested in a limited China deal, according to an aide. Seemingly contradicting earlier comments from the President who when asked about an interim deal he said he ‘guesses’ he could see one happening but would prefer a full deal. The overall atmospherics of the trade deputy trade meeting were however questioned, as the Montana Farm Bureau, as well as Nebraska’s department of agriculture, announced that the China delegation were no longer going to be visiting the farming states in the US, and that they have ended their trip early, heading back to China. Elsewhere, away from trade, Trump did raise the alarm that “China, in a sense, is a threat to the world” because of its military build-up.

* REPO TIMETABLE: The New York Fed announced it will be conducting overnight repo-operations every trading day until October, 10th at a minimum amount of USD 75bln, with three 14-day term operations of at least USD 30bln next week; this - for the short - term will provide some reassurance to the funding market. Fed’s Clarida said the Fed acted decisively to combat the repo shock and reiterated Fed Chair Powell's line of thinking, that the repo issues are not a sign of concern for the economy. At the tail-end of the session the FT released an exclusive interview with NY Fed President Williams (voter) who questioned the hesitance of banks in the repo market, and that the focus should be on how the market functions and not the level of reserves at the Fed. Williams failed to provide much clarity but Senior VP at NY Fed Markets Group Logan alluded to the concentration of cash at a small number of banks as one potential issue, adding that the NY Fed had expected that as the repo rate rose, banks would withdraw cash at the Fed and lend it to the repo market, but this didn't materialize and the Fed had to launch its own repo operations.

* FED: Fed's Rosengren (hawk, voted for no cut) stated his reasons for dissenting the 25bp cut, citing labour markets as already tight, current US monetary policy being accommodative, the fed funds target rate below the inflation target, low interest rates encouraging more leverage in underwritten riskier debt transactions, and that lowering rates to address trade and geopolitical risks is not costless. The Boston Fed President added later that reserve scarcity in the financial system is a solvable problem, whilst nodding to building permits and jobless claims as supportive of the economy. Fed's Bullard (dove, voted for 50bps cut) said he dissented from the 25bps cut decision as a larger cut was more appropriate, there are signs US growth is to slow soon, manufacturing appears to be in recession, (PCE) inflation measures continue to run below the target, and that it is prudent risk management to cut the policy rate aggressively now then later increase it, should the downside risks not materialize. Fed's Clarida (voter) reiterated the party line, saying the Fed will act as appropriate – being data attentive - to sustain the expansion, whilst acknowledging a “clearly” slowing global economy. The Fed Vice Chair noted the range of views on the Fed's committee but said they all agree they are in a good place. When asked about more cuts ahead, Clarida said he doesn’t want to put probabilities on another cut this year.

* SAUDI-IRAN: US President Trump provided the details of the fresh sanctions, declaring them on the Iranian National Bank and Iran’s sovereign wealth fund. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin labelled them "very big" and that they remove the last source of funding for Iran. Trump was reported to receive drafts of military strike options on Friday but has not yet definitively announced whether they will be executed, and when asked about the military option, Trump said the US is always prepared; Trump also reiterated that a military option would work but should never have to use it, expects sanctions to work. Over in the Gulf, Sputnik reported an Iranian Envoy saying Iran is to keep reducing its Nuclear Deal commitments on a 60-day basis, but no decision has been decided on its 4th stage of reductions. The Yemen Houthis said they were to stop targeting Saudi territories, but they expect a “similar” announcement in return from Saudi. CBS reported that the US had positioned the USS Nitze - a destroyer armed with surface to air missiles - off the NE coast of Saudi to cover the gap in its air defences. Iran's Oil Minister Zanganeh has also reportedly ordered preparations for cyber-attacks against its oil infrastructure.

* RANSQUAWK CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY - REVIEWING: FED, BOJ, BOE, NORGES, SNB, BCB, SARB. PREVIEWING: BANXICO AND RBNZ. Click here to download the report.

* BREXIT: Yesterday’s ‘positive’ comments from EC President Juncker have been downplayed, as it appeared to be rather stale comments with still no breakthrough. The proposals to the backstop were yet to be seen, however now they have, EU officials are seemingly not impressed, with Irish Foreign Minister Coveney saying the proposals do not stand up to scrutiny, and sources stating UK PM Johnsons ‘non-paper’ proposals are seen as a waste of time in Brussels, according to ITV. Also, EU27 diplomats reportedly said the non-papers were ‘horrible’, according to FT. In response to the ‘horrible’ proposals, the UK reportedly did not seem too pleased as The Sun reported, citing sources “The ideas we’ve put forward to avoid a hard border are serious and workable. As for Commission, two months ago they said there was absolutely no alternative to the backstop.” adding, “What we’re focussed on is getting a deal in the room. We trust they’ll do the same.” FT also reported that UK PM Johnson told colleagues he does not expect to be able to reach a full “legally operable” deal covering the Irish border at the meeting of EU leader, further clouding the prospects of a deal with the EU.

* WTI (X9) SETTLED USD 0.10 LOWER AT USD 58.08/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLED USD 0.12 LOWER AT USD 64.28/BBL: Crude futures traded rangebound and subdued to end the week with participants cautious ahead of the weekend. The Trump administration announced fresh “highest ever” sanctions on Iran but did not announce a military strike, nor did it rule the option out, leaving an element of uncertainty on the potential for more oil supply disruptions. However, oil prices were victim to the risk-off move on reports that the Chinese agricultural delegation were heading home earlier than expected, seeing benchmarks push to session lows into the settlement. Looking on the week, oil prices are firmer - with Brent trading at an approximate USD 4/bbl premium to the close last week – albeit significantly off their record, leg-open highs set on Monday, where Brent printed just shy of USD 72/bbl, as the market’s fears of supply disruption have been swiftly alleviated with gratitude to Saudi Aramco’s reassurance it could maintain its production; participants are still paying close attention to the physical market to gain confirmation of theses promises, however.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 3 TICKS HIGHER AT 129-22. Treasuries caught a bid in the tail-end of the session and going into the weekend (after trading mainly sideways) in the latest risk-off flows as the Chinese delegation announced it was leaving the US earlier than it had anticipated. There was some support for the TPLEX earlier, taking cues from Bunds, after Germany announced new climate budget plans would be financed via taxes, otherwise little else had much effect on Friday. At settlement yields were lower by around 3bps with spreads mixed.

* US-JAPAN: The US is unlikely to remove tariffs on imports of Japanese auto-parts in their trade agreement - due to be signed next week - Japanese Times reported citing sources. The newly appointed Japanese Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi has recently been seeking confirmation in the talks that no additional tariffs would be placed on Japanese cars.

* CANADA RETAIL SALES: July retail sales picked up from June to 0.4% from a prior revised -0.1%, albeit missing expectations for a 0.6% rise. Core retail sales declined this month missing expectations, printing -0.1%, lower than the 0.3% expected and much lower than the prior months 0.9% gain. Auto sales led the increase in the headline however a decline in building materials, gasoline and clothing weighed on the reading. RBC expect household spending will continue to grow at a respectable, if unspectacular, pace over H2 19. Adding it will probably be needed as elevated uncertainties remain regarding the potential spill over effect of international trade into the manufacturing sales activity.

* GERMAN FISCAL SPENDING: German Chancellor Merkel said we remain committed to a balanced budget and not incurring new debt. Finance Minister Scholz said Germany would finance its climate package with taxes, which saw Bunds rise.

* PBOC: The central bank cut its 1-year Loan Prime Rate to 4.2% (Prev. 4.25%), in line with expectations. However, left its 5-year LPR unchanged at 4.85%, where some had expected a cut to 4.8%. The cut to the 1-year rate was the second consecutive month in a bid to reduce borrowing costs for companies and consumers impacted by the trade war. The 5-year, however, was left unchanged to keep property prices under control, as it is used as a reference for mortgage loans. The cut was expected following the PBoC’s RRR cut to improve liquidity. This took effect Monday where 50bp was trimmed off the RRR, with some being offered a 100bp cut in the coming months. The 50bp cut freed up CNY 800bln in liquidity, and once the 100bp cuts are implemented (Oct15 & Nov15), a further CNY 100bln will be freed.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -0.5% at 2992, NASDAQ-100 -1% at 7824, Dow Jones  -0.6% at 26934

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -1.2%, Consumer Staples  -0.2%, Energy  0.1%, Financials  -0.6%, Health Care  0.6%, Industrials  -0.7%, Information Technology  -1.1%, Materials  -0.2%, Telecommunication Services  -0.5%, Utilities  0.4%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Netflix (NFLX) tumbled as its CEO announced a challenging outlook due to growing competition and Evercore suggested a risk of disappointing Q3 international subscribers. Roku (ROKU) nosedived on Pinnacle initiating the streaming device maker at a Sell rating, citing increasing competition. PG&E (PCG) suffered from a new USD 24bln wildfire victim reorganisation plan. Eli Lilly (LLY) opened higher after receiving label approval from European regulators for a diabetes treatment. Merck (MRK) was bolstered by the FDA expanded label use for two HIV treatments. United Rentals (URI) benefited from an upgrade to a Buy rating at Goldman Sachs. Regeneron (REGN) outperformed after receiving European recommended approval for another use of its Dupixient. Xilinx (XLNX) opened on the backfoot after its CFO departed unexpectedly. Harley Davidson (HOG) was firmer due to UBS forecasting a less-severe outlook. Wayfair (W) was initiated with a Sell rating at Berenberg, citing competition.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP:

USD: The Dollar has bounced firmly across the board amidst a broad downturn in risk sentiment following reports that US President Trump is not keen on striking a mini or interim deal with China on trade, while seemingly rising prospects of a Brexit deal have been dashed by UK PM Johnson playing down the chances of being able to reach a full legally operational arrangement for the Irish border at next month’s EU Summit. However, the DXY remains just off best levels seen so far this week (98.749) within a 98.621-139 range and initial post-FOMC highs on ‘hawkish cut’ perceptions. To recap, the Fed eased by 25 bp, but retained an upbeat assessment of the economy overall and the SEP dot plots did not explicitly map out any further cuts this year or in 2020. Nevertheless, the accompanying statement maintained that action will be taken as appropriate to sustain growth and keep inflation on track towards target, while Powell stressed uncertainty over the outlook in the press conference and Q&A. Meanwhile, the NY Fed responded to a significant imbalance in the overnight repo market caused by Treasury coupon payments coinciding with corporate tax payments and perhaps exacerbated by margin calls on short crude positions due to a sharp spike in underlying oil prices following attacks on 2 major Saudi Arabian sites last weekend by injecting liquidity for the 1st time in 10 years, and subsequently announced more 1 day ops and 3 term repos (14 day maturities).

JPY/CHF/GBP/NOK: The Yen ends the week coming off the 108.00 level and mid-range vs the Greenback, with underlying support from the BoJ keeping rates and YCC bands unchanged, but also bolstered by its safe-haven appeal. Similarly, the Franc derived impetus via the SNB resisting any temptation to match last week’s 10 bp ECB cut or upgrade its assessment of the Swiss currency, while sweetening NIRP exemption terms for banks via an even more generous factor 25 vs 20. Conversely, Sterling largely shrugged off another BoE policy meeting ending with small and limited tightening guidance based on a smooth Brexit, and was more responsive to UK data (soft CPI and retail sales) before going on a tear when EU’s Juncker held out the possibility of a breakthrough on the Irish backstop, with full compliance of the border objectives. However, the Pound suffered a pretty pronounced fall from grace and reality check (Cable recoiling from circa 1.2580 to around 1.2460, though still above sub-1.2400 lows, and Eur/Gbp back over 0.8800) when Ireland’s Foreign Minister and various EU officials claimed that Britain has still not delivered proposals that are compatible with the principles of the existing WA. Elsewhere, the Norwegian Krona also witnessed an abrupt change of direction with Eur/Nok declining in immediate response to the ¼ point Norges Bank hike that was seen as 50-50 going into the verdict, but the cross then rebounding all the way up to 9.9730+ from just above 9.8120 in acknowledgement of a shallower rate path and Governor Olson assigning a 40% probability to further tightening.

NZD/AUD/CAD: All on the back foot and much nearer worst levels vs their US counterparts than highs, with the Kiwi extending losses through 0.6300 ahead of next week’s RNBZ meeting in apprehension that easing expectations will be confirmed via forward guidance if not action, while outside calls for an RBA cut in October have grown in wake of dovish minutes and disappointing Aussie jobs data to leave Aud/Usd further away from 0.6800 and not far from 0.6900 at one stage. The Loonie is holding up a bit better between 1.3207-1.3309 parameters, but not helped by benign Canadian CPI a decline in retail sales or oil coming off the boil as Saudi’s Aramco aims to restore all of the 50% output loss by the end of September. Note also, election uncertainty has kept Usd/Cad elevated.

EUR: The single currency has been mainly tracking swings in risk appetite/aversion, while keeping tabs on Eurozone political developments (Spain and Italy), yield differentials and the ongoing fall-out from last Thursday’s ECB stimulus package. However, rebounds towards 1.1100 vs the Buck have faded and become increasingly shallow amidst heavy option expiry interest and chart resistance on top of economic indicators and inflation data underlining slowdown or even recession tendencies ahead of preliminary PMIs due at the start of next week.

EM: Very volatile trade in regional currencies and the aforementioned sour tone on Friday has taken its toll amidst heightened geopolitical/Middle East tensions, as the US unveiled more sanctions against Iran. However, the Real also factored in another 50 bp BCB rate cut and while the SARB stood pat there was enough in the accompanying statements to signal an easing bias and the Rand has recoiled towards 15.0000 vs the Dollar compared to highs close to 14.5000. Elsewhere, CBRT minutes have compounded rate cut expectations via a dovish inflation outlook, with the Lira also jittery about the US imposing sanctions due to Turkey’s S-400 Russian purchase and Syrian military actions. Conversely, Indian tax cuts have bolstered the Rupee and the Indonesian Rupiah has welcomed another 25bp BNI rate cut.

20th September 2019

  • The focal Quad-Witching falls on Friday, with expiries across futures and options expiring across indices and stocks, with desks noting potential for volatility as investors square their books.
  • BofAML’s latest Flow Show has its Bull & Bear Indicator still in extreme bear territory, although latest weekly flows show USD 19.2bln into equities, “inflows to EM stocks (1st since April) & financials, outflows from healthcare & utilities.”

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) requests to bypass tariffs on Chinese imports are reportedly moving through the review process, despite President Trump saying he would rebuff them. Elsewhere, BofA analyst Wamsi Mohan said his shipping tracking data showed stronger pre-orders than last year’s cycle, and both Longbow analyst Shawn Harrison and Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty said their data suggested the same. Meanwhile, JPMorgan analyst Samik Chatterjee suggested Apple revenue rose for a sixth consecutive month in August, the desk adds the demand for iPhone 11 is outpacing supply chain expectations.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp.’s (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) infrastructure megaproject in Iraq is in danger, where Energy Intel reports that Iraq is warming to Chinese competitors to replace Exxon for the project.
  • Intel Corp. (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has been ordering equipment and other resources for EUV fabrication processes since August, where DigiTimes reports it is ramping up orders currently.
  • McDonald's Corp. (MCD) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) has raised its quarterly dividend by 8% to USD 1.25/shr.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) has appointed GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) CEO Emma Walmsley to its board of directors.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is to make an additional EUR 3bln of investment in its European data centres over the next two years, CEO Sundar Pichai whilst in his trip to Finland.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) CEO Jeff Bezos has announced plans to make Amazon carbon neutral by 2040, where he expects 80% of energy to come from renewable sources by 2024, before transitioning to zero emissions by 2030, CNBC reports.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with President Trump, who tweeted that they had a “nice meeting”, as part of Zuckerberg’s trip to Washington to gain more government support for FB.
  • Netflix Inc. (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) CEO Reed Hastings is looking to make a “big increase” in the content it buys in the UK to take advantage of its experience in storytelling.
  • Texas Instruments (TXN) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has raised its quarterly dividend to USD 0.90/shr from USD 0.77/shr.
  • Xilinx (XLNX) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) CFO Lorenzo Flores is leaving the Co to pursue other opportunities following Xilinx’s earnings on October 23rd, the Co has launched a replacement search.

S&P 500

  • Carnival Corp. (CCL) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) has received approval for the expansion of a cruise terminal in Miami which will enable the support of its new Excel class ship.
  • Eli Lilly & Co. (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) will pay AC Immune (ACIU) its first milestone payment of CHF 30mln as a sign of progress being made on their Phase 1 study of ACI-3024, an Alzheimer's and other neurodegenerative disorders treatment.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) talks with strike leader UAW have made “some progress”, according to a UAW official, but caveats that many issues remain unresolved, according to local press.
  • KeyCorp (KEY) (Financials/Regional Banks) CEO Beth Mooney is to retire on May 1st, 2020, where newly appointed COO Chris Gorman will succeed her.
  • Progressive Corp. (PGR) (Financials/Property & Casualty Insurance) has promoted Jonathan Bauer to CIO following the retirement of William Cody, effective January 3rd, 2020.
  • S&P Global, Inc.’s (SPGI) (Financials/Financial Exchanges & Data) S&P Dow Jones Indices unit CEO Alexander Matturri announced his retirement.

OTHER

  • Beyond Meat Inc (BYND) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) has appointed Sanjay Shah as its new COO, effective September 18th, who brings experience from positions at Amazon (AMZN) and Tesla (TSLA).
  • PG&E (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) – A representative group of wildfire victims have reached an agreement with the Co’s bondholders for a USD 24bln trust for victim compensation, clearing the path for PG&E’s bankruptcy to be cleared by the June 2020 deadline.
  • Square Inc (SQ) (Information Technology/IT Services) has had its PT lowered to USD 75 from USD 100 at KeyBanc, where analyst Josh Beck cites analysis showing a scenario of flatter PF margins vs. market expectations of close to 200bps of expansion.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 20th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer this morning in largely tentative trade as markets pause after a hectic week
  • NY Fed announced a fourth consecutive overnight repo operation of USD 75bln at a minimum bid rate of 1.8% for Friday at 0815-0830 ET
  • Fed’s Bullard says he dissented as a large cut is more appropriate, cites soft PCE & signs the economy is to slow soon
  • The FX space is similarly tentative with the USD little changed vs. G10 counterparts
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian Retail Sales, Fed’s Rosengren & Kaplan and Quadruple Witching

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed/flat as risk appetite picked slightly up from the indecision seen on Wall St where stocks meandered amid a slew of central bank announcements, in which the DJIA failed to hold on to early gains and finished lower and the S&P 500 returned flat despite an initial approach to within 6 points of its all-time high. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was underpinned by increasing expectations for the RBA to lower rates next month and with gold miners front-running the gains after the precious metal reclaimed the psychological key USD 1500/oz level, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was also higher but with upside restricted by currency flows and amid mixed inflation data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were indecisive following mixed trade-related rhetoric as NEC Director Kudlow suggested a softer US-China mood, while President Trump’s advisor Pillsbury warned the President is ready to escalate the trade war if a deal is not agreed soon and that tariffs could increase to 50% or 100%. PBoC actions were also somewhat ambiguous as the central bank cut its 1yr Loan Prime Rate by 5bps to 4.20% as expected but refrained from a similar anticipated cut to the 5yr Loan Price Rate of 4.85% and although it announced another substantial injection of CNY 120bln in reverse repos today, its total operations including MLFs resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 15bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower and yields increased amid the positive tone in Japan and after the BoJ rinban announcement in which it reduced purchase amounts in all of today’s maturities from the belly to super-long end, although prices later recovered to trade near-flat.

PBoC 1yr Loan Prime Rate set at 4.20% vs. Exp. 4.20% (Prev. 4.25%). (Newswires) PBoC 5yr Loan Prime Rate set at 4.85% vs. Exp. 4.80% (Prev. 4.85%)

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 80bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0730 vs. Exp. 7.0807 (Prev. 7.0732)

PBoC announced to sell CNY 10bln of bank bills in Hong Kong on September 26th. 

Japanese National CPI (Aug) Y/Y 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Aug) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%); slowest increase since Jul 2017 Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Aug) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%)

US

Fed's Bullard (Voter, dovish dissenter) says he dissented from the recent Fed rate cut decision because a larger cut was more appropriate, says there are signs US growth is to slow soon and manufacturing appears to be in recession

- core and headline PCE measures continue to run some 40 to 60 basis points, respectively, below the FOMC’s 2% inflation target.

- is prudent risk management to cut the policy rate aggressively now and then later increase it should the downside risks not materialize

NY Fed announced a fourth consecutive overnight repo operation of USD 75bln at a minimum bid rate of 1.8% for Friday at 0815-0830 ET. (Newswires)

US House has approved a stopgap measure to fund the government to November 21st which heads to the Senate. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi-led coalition conducted a military operation in Yemen in which it destroyed 4 locations used for assembling remote-controlled boats and sea mines. (Newswires)

Saudi Aramco Executive states that the attacks on the Khurais oil infrastructure targeted 4 locations in their oil production facilities; confident we will be back to full production by the end of September. (Newswires)

Kuwait Foreign Minister is said to have received a call from Iran Foreign Minister Zarif in which they discussed regional developments as well as how to de-escalate tensions. (Newswires)

North Korea reportedly may be preparing a submarine capable of launching ballistic missiles. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney says UK proposals on the backstop do not stand up to scrutiny. (Newswires)

EU are eager to arrive at a deal, EU sources state that are ready to look again (compromise) on the current backstop, but will not accept its removal unless there is a watertight UK alternative., BBC's Adler. (Twitter)

UK Trade Secretary Truss met with Japanese Foreign Minister Motegi in which she stated the UK is interested in joining CPTPP trade group and wants an ambitious trade deal with Japan. (Newswires)

Incoming ECB President Lagarde said global growth is fragile and under threat, while she added that central bankers must be predictable and focus on stability. (Newswires)

German Finance Ministry said the domestic economy began Q3 on a weaker footing amid subdued global economy and uncertainties, while it sees a continued contraction in industrial output and no sign of change to the negative trend of exports. Furthermore, it added the labour market is getting impetus from the services sector but growth in overall employment is slowing down. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are firmer (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.5%) following a mostly positive Asia-Pac lead, trading in relatively thin ranges as the market takes a breather following the prior two day’s flurry of Central Bank activity; with indices having picked up somewhat from their relatively unchanged start as the session progressed. Some choppiness has been seen however; and it is worth noting that it is Quadruple witching day, with September contracts set to expire for a number of European and US single stock, index and option futures. Underperformance is being seen in the FTSE100 (-0.3%) as GBP strengthens on the back of growing Brexit deal hopes. The sectors are relatively mixed, and unreflective of any particular risk configuration; Energy, Consumer Discretionary, Health Care, Financials, Telecoms and Utilities are higher while Materials and Industrials are lower. In terms of notable individual movers; Thomas Cook Group (-17.0%) sunk on premarket news that recapitalisation and reorganisation discussions are continuing, may result in the interest of existing shareholders being significantly diluted and poses the risk of no recovery. RBS (+3.6%) moved higher on the news that the company had hired former Natwest Markets head Alison Rose as CEO. A disappointing trade update from Investec (-6.2%), in which H1 EPS guidance was revised lower, saw shares sell off. Finally, Casino (+2.5%) moved higher on the news that the Co. had entered into discussions with Aldi France re. the potential acquisition of Leader Price.

Exxon (XOM) - Reports indicate that Iraq is moving towards Chinese Co's to replace the Co. for a infrastructure mega-project., according to Energy Intel citing sources. (Energy Intel)

Uber (UBER) - Uber's temporary London license runs out next week; reports indicate that a deal is likely from TFL but this will not be for the usual 5-year term., LBC's Usherwood. (Twitter)

FX

GBP - The Pound remains perky, but not quite so brimming with Brexit breakthrough optimism after EU’s Juncker sparked a short squeeze by intimating that a deal can still be done before the October 31 deadline on the premise that Irish border conditions are met by any alternative arrangement put forward by the UK. His hopeful remarks were backed up by Britain’s Junior Brexit Minister, but dampened by Irish Foreign Minister Coveney and reports that EU officials are frustrated that practical solutions have still not been provided by PM Johnson. Cable extended gains to and just beyond offers at 1.2580, but faded ahead of Fib resistance at 1.2589 and is now back below 1.2550, while Eur/Gbp stopped just short of support below 0.8800 (at 0.8777) and has subsequently rebounded through the big figure and a 0.8809 Fib.

CHF - Still holding a firmer line in wake of yesterday’s SNB Quarterly Policy review when benchmark rates were left unchanged against some expectations for an ease to counter last week’s 10 bp ECB cut, and inflation projections were based on steady policy throughout the forecast horizon. COMMODITIES

The crude complex trades higher on Friday morning, in quiet trade that mirrors the broader lack of conviction elsewhere. In terms of recent geopolitical developments; a Saudi-led coalition conducted a military operation in Yemen, destroying 4 locations reportedly being used for assembling remote-controlled boats and sea mines. Elsewhere, there were reports that US national security officials met yesterday to draft possible action against Iran and to refine a list of potential targets to strike in the event that President Trump were to order a military retaliation. In terms of metals; Gold is higher on the day, but continues to linger around the USD 1500/oz mark. China's Energy Administration states that if there is no trade war then China would be able to import large quantities of oil and gas from the US. (Newswires)

Some choppiness has been seen however; and it is worth noting that it is Quadruple witching day, with September contracts set to expire for a number of European and US single stock, index and option futures. Underperformance is being seen in the FTSE100 (-0.3%) as GBP strengthens on the back of growing Brexit deal hopes.   • adds core and headline personal consumption expenditures (PCE) inflation measures continue to run some 40 to 60 basis points, respectively, below the FOMC’s 2% inflation target.
  • says it is prudent risk management to cut the policy rate aggressively now rather than later increase it should the downside risks not materialize.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures factoring in Brexit breakthrough
content: UK debt and STIR contracts pared some losses when Ireland’s Foreign Minister poured cold water on rising prospects of a compromise to the backstop impasse, stoked by latest comments from EU’s Juncker ahead of a meeting between Brexit Minister Barclay and the EU’s chief negotiator Barnier later today. However, the Pound remains bid across the board and content or relieved that there might be a glimmer of hope for a breakthrough or middle ground on the border impasse, with remarks by Britain’s Junior Brexit Minister adding to the positivity. Hence, Gilts are on the back foot again within a 132.16-47 early Liffe range vs Thursday’s 132.59 close and the 3 month strip is slipping back towards worst levels of 2.5-5 ticks below parity.

subject: Bunds: probing resistance around 173.50 and support circa -50 bp
content: Amidst what looks like hefty upside call buying in US long bonds and yet more weak Eurozone inflation data via German PPI, the 10 year German benchmark has been grinding higher in early trade, but looks reluctant or hesitant to extend gains through 173.50 as the corresponding cash yield edges tentatively through -50 bp. Bunds may be biding time to see how cash bourses fare off the open, while conscious that Gilts could play catch-up with weaker Short Sterling contracts on Brexit grounds and sap bullish sentiment from core bond counterparts in contagion.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

20th September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly positively as risk appetite picked up from the indecision seen on Wall St where stocks meandered amid a slew of central bank announcements, in which the DJIA failed to hold on to early gains and finished lower and the S&P 500 returned flat despite an initial approach to within 6 points of its all-time high. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was underpinned by increasing expectations for the RBA to lower rates next month and with gold miners front-running the gains after the precious metal reclaimed the psychological key USD 1500/oz level, while Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was also higher but with upside restricted by currency flows and amid mixed inflation data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were indecisive following mixed trade-related rhetoric as NEC Director Kudlow suggested a softer US-China mood, while President Trump’s advisor Pillsbury warned the President is ready to escalate the trade war if a deal is not agreed soon and that tariffs could increase to 50% or 100%. PBoC actions were also somewhat ambiguous as the central bank cut its 1yr Loan Prime Rate by 5bps to 4.20% as expected but refrained from a similar anticipated cut to the 5yr Loan Price Rate of 4.85% and although it announced another substantial injection of CNY 120bln in reverse repos today, its total operations including MLFs resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 15bln.

FTSE 100

LSE (LSE LN) – The Italian government has approved measures protect Italy’s Milan Stock Exchange, should non-EU players seek to stake-build, sources said. Non-EU players will be forced to notify the government, should they wish to build a stake in key Italian financial infrastructure. (Newswires)

BAE Systems (BAE LN) – Co. has been awarded a USD 495mln contract modification against a previous five-year contract with the US Department of Defence. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Co’s banks are demanding the Co. acquires an additional GBP 200mln funding as a contingency fund for the winter., as such the vote for the GBP 900mln Fosun rescue plan has been postponed to Friday 27th September. Which has reportedly angered shareholders as they believe the banking syndicate, led by RBS (RBS LN), is pushing the Co. towards collapsing. Additionally, Co. has had emergency discussions to sell their Nordic airline and tour units to generate the required funding. (BBC/Telegraph/Sky)

BROKER MOVES

BURBERRY GROUP (BRBY LN) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

DAX

Deutsche Bourse (DB1 GY) – Board member Hauke Stars is to leave the management board of the co. when her contract ends in November 2020. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

ADIDAS (ADS GY) INITIATED WITH MARKET PERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Casino (CO FP) – Co. has confirmed that it has entered into discussions with Aldi France re. the potential acquisition of leader price. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

European Co’s [Notably, Airbus (AIR FP)] – EU could retaliate to US tariffs related to aircraft subsidies by using old WTO awards in unrelated disputes to quickly impose duties on US goods if Washington doesn't agree to a settlement. (Politico)

Phillips (PHIA NA) – Co. are to sell their remaining 10.7% stake in Signify (LIGHT NA) (formerly Phillips Lighting). (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM) – Co. and Peninsula Holdings have agreed for Peninsula to purchase up to 355mln shares of the Co’s Pan-Europe platform from investors, to be purchased at a discount to the withdrawal rights levels, in order to mitigate the potential for Vivendi (VIV FP) to impact Co’s plan to generate a Pan-European platform. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ENEL (ENEL IM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

SMI

UBS (UBSG SW) – Co’s Beijing Securities arm is reportedly planning on increasing fees on arranging sales on the STAR market to approximately 20% of its mainland stock underwriting income by the years end. With aims to have this increase to 50% by next year., according to sources. (Newswires)

Roche (ROG SW) – FDA has approved Cobas Babesia, the co.’s first whole blood test for donor screening. (Newswires)

Clariant (CLN SW) – Co. and Orlen Poludnie have announced a new license agreement on Sunliquid Cellulosic Ethanol Technology. The Co.’s reportedly intend to build a ‘full-scale’ commercial production plant in Poland. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were indecisive following mixed trade-related rhetoric as NEC Director Kudlow suggested a softer US-China mood, while President Trump’s advisor Pillsbury warned the President is ready to escalate the trade war if a deal is not agreed soon and that tariffs could increase to 50% or 100%. PBoC actions were also somewhat ambiguous as the central bank cut its 1yr Loan Prime Rate by 5bps to 4.20% as expected but refrained from a similar anticipated cut to the 5yr Loan Price Rate of 4.85% and although it announced another substantial injection of CNY 120bln in reverse repos today, its total operations including MLFs resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 15bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower and yields increased amid the positive tone in Japan and after the BoJ rinban announcement in which it reduced purchase amounts in all of today’s maturities from the belly to super-long end, although prices later recovered to trade near-flat.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 80bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0730 vs. Exp. 7.0807 (Prev. 7.0732)

PBoC announced to sell CNY 10bln of bank bills in Hong Kong on September 26th.

 

US President Trump advisor Michael Pillsbury said the President is ready to escalate the trade war if a deal is not agreed soon and that tariffs could go to 50% or 100%. (SCMP) 

US Agricultural Secretary Perdue said the Chinese delegation wants to see US agricultural production and build good will in its planned visits to US farms next week. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said current talks should be cherished by both sides and that US officials misread China's goodwill thinking it shows Beijing's weakness, while he added that China is not as anxious to get a deal as the US. (Twitter)

Japanese National CPI (Aug) Y/Y 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Aug) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%); slowest increase since Jul 2017 Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Aug) Y/Y 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said he believes there is some progress in Brexit talks but will see where things go. UK and EU are said to be discussing a condition for any agreement set, in which no further extension will be offered. Such a move would mean that if MPs refuse to accept any potential deal, then the alternative will be no deal. (Newswires/Spectator)

EU Commission President Juncker said think we can have a Brexit deal and that Brexit will happen, while he added the EU are prepared for a no-deal and hopes Britain is prepared as well but is not so sure. Furthermore, Juncker said he had a meeting with UK PM Johnson that was rather positive and that he is doing everything to have a deal because he thinks a no-deal would have catastrophic consequences for at least one year. Juncker also confirmed he had received the proposals from the British government but haven’t had the opportunity to read them yet, while he suggested if all the objectives are met, then we don't need the backstop. (Sky News)

UK Trade Secretary Truss met with Japanese Foreign Minister Motegi in which she stated the UK is interested in joining CPTPP trade group and wants an ambitious trade deal with Japan. (Newswires)

Incoming ECB President Lagarde said global growth is fragile and under threat, while she added that central bankers must be predictable and focus on stability. (Newswires)

German Finance Ministry said the domestic economy began Q3 on a weaker footing amid subdued global economy and uncertainties, while it sees a continued contraction in industrial output and no sign of change to the negative trend of exports. Furthermore, it added the labour market is getting impetus from the services sector but growth in overall employment is slowing down. (Newswires)

EU could retaliate to US tariffs related to aircraft subsidies by using old WTO awards in unrelated disputes to quickly impose duties on US goods if Washington doesn't agree to a settlement. (Politico)

FX

 

DXY was flat following the prior day’s post-FOMC fade in which it took a back seat to the flurry of global central bank updates, while EUR/USD resumed the prior day’s swings but with price action kept within a tight range near a large option expiry at 1.1050 for today’s New York cut. GBP/USD remained firmer after comments from EU’s Juncker lifted the currency to 2-month highs. Elsewhere, USD/JPY retreated below the 108.00 handle as yields increased after the BoJ reduced its bond buying amounts, while antipodeans were lacklustre with AUD/USD initially pressured as Citi and NAB joined in on the RBA October cut bandwagon although the losses were eventually reversed as CNY strengthened following a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting and bill sale announcement in Hong Kong which some previously touted as a tool used to support the mainland currency. 

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities saw mild gains overnight in which WTI crude futures continued its rebound from the prior day’s trough amid US output disruption concerns from adverse weather conditions and lingering geopolitical uncertainty surrounding Iran, while the Saudi-led coalition also conducted a military operation against several targets in Yemen. Elsewhere, gold prices edged higher above the USD 1500/oz level after the greenback gave back all of its FOMC-related gains and copper also conformed to the mild gains across the complex amid the somewhat improved risk sentiment.

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi-led coalition conducted a military operation in Yemen in which it destroyed 4 locations used for assembling remote-controlled boats and sea mines. (Newswires)

US national security officials met yesterday to draft possible action against Iran and to refine a list of potential targets to strike in the event that President Trump were to order a military retaliation. (NY Times)

Kuwait Foreign Minister is said to have received a call from Iran Foreign Minister Zarif in which they discussed regional developments as well as how to de-escalate tensions. (Newswires)

North Korea reportedly may be preparing a submarine capable of launching ballistic missiles. (Newswires)

 

US

Treasuries moved slightly higher throughout the day with participants digesting the latest FOMC meeting, a third day of Fed repo operations, in addition to the brewing geopolitical backdrop; by settlement yields were lower across the curve by a basis point or two. The Fed accepted USD 75bln of the USD 83.875bln worth of bids received for its overnight repo operation. Another oversubscribed overnight repo implies continued stress and appears to allude to an ongoing liquidity shortage, which could be more than a short-term phenomenon; the Fed has announced a fourth consecutive overnight operation for Friday at the same time and terms of Thursday. The operations have not, as of yet, had a material impact further out the Treasury curve, but if the “temporary” operations become increasingly less temporary there is potential for the changing dynamics of short-term funding to work its way into longer maturities. Elsewhere, The US funding announcement for 2s, 5s, and 7s remained at an unchanged nominal amount. The Treasury also sold USD 12bln of 10-year TIPS, stopping through by 0.5bps at a high rate of 0.174%. US T-note futures (z9) settled 6+ ticks higher at 129-19.

NY Fed announced a fourth consecutive overnight repo operation of USD 75bln at a minimum bid rate of 1.8% for Friday at 0815-0830 ET. (Newswires)

US House has approved a stopgap measure to fund the government to November 21st which heads to the Senate. (Newswires)

PBoC actions were also somewhat ambiguous as the central bank cut its 1yr Loan Prime Rate by 5bps to 4.20% as expected but refrained from a similar anticipated cut to the 5yr Loan Price Rate of 4.85% and although it announced another substantial injection of CNY 120bln in reverse repos today, its total operations including MLFs resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 15bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower and yields increased amid the positive tone in Japan and after the BoJ rinban announcement in which it reduced purchase amounts in all of today’s maturities from the belly to super-long end, although prices later recovered to trade near-flat.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly positive but with gains capped after Wall St indecision and this week's slew of central bank updates
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly positive as risk appetite attempts to pick up from the indecision seen on Wall St where stocks meandered amid a slew of central bank announcements, in which the DJIA failed to hold on to early gains and finished lower and the S&P 500 returned flat despite initially approaching to within 6 points of its all-time high. ASX 200 (+0.6%) is underpinned by increasing expectations for the RBA to lower rates next month and with gold miners front-running the gains after the precious metal reclaimed the psychological key USD 1500/oz level, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) is also higher but with upside restricted by currency flows and amid mixed inflation data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) are indecisive following mixed trade-related rhetoric as NEC Director Kudlow suggested a softer US-China mood, while President Trump’s advisor Pillsbury warned the President is ready to escalate the trade war if a deal is not agreed soon and tariffs could increase to 50% or 100%. The PBoC actions were also somewhat ambiguous as the central bank cut its 1yr Loan Prime Rate by 5bps to 4.20% as expected but refrained from a similar anticipated cut to the 5yr Loan Price Rate of 4.85% and although it announced another substantial injection of CNY 120bln in reverse repos today, its total operations including MLFs have resulted to a net weekly drain of CNY 15bln.

In FX markets, the DXY is flat following the prior day’s-post FOMC fade in which it took a back seat to the flurry of global central bank updates, while its major counterpart EUR/USD resumes the prior day’s swings but with price action kept within a tight range near a large option expiry at 1.1050 for today’s New York cut. GBP/USD remains firmer after comments from EU’s Juncker lifted the currency to 2-month highs as he thinks a Brexit deal can be made and suggested a backstop won’t be needed if all the objectives are met. Elsewhere, USD/JPY retreated below the 108.00 handle as yields increased after the BoJ reduced its bond buying amounts, while antipodeans were lacklustre with AUD/USD initially pressured as Citi and NAB joined in on the RBA October cut bandwagon although the losses were eventually counterbalanced following a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting.

Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower and yields increased amid the positive tone in Japan and after the BoJ rinban announcement in which it reduced purchase amounts in all of today’s maturities from the belly to super-long end.
